abstracts.cdata!:
The project rating is unsatisfactory,
            and sustainability is unlikely. The lessons strongly
            emphasize that, when streamlining institutions, project
            design should explicitly identify the staff whose expertise
            will no longer be required, and in turn, include incentives
            to retain staff with desirable skills. In addition, project
            design should have also ensured financing arrangements upon
            the transfer of an autonomous entity, operating on
            semi-commercial terms, into a budget-supported entity, for
            instead of allowing full concentration to extension
            services, such entity also carried the burden of generating
            their own funds, further increasing their bureaucracy, and
            dependency on central ministerial services. The concept of
            "polyvalence of extension agents" proved
            inefficient, and costly, and the quality of service to
            producers was not improved. However, empowering farmers, and
            communities with responsibilities, including financial
            resources management, and appropriate training, contributed
            to successful partnerships in development, effectively
            negotiating with the Government, and donors. Nonetheless,
            the diversity of co-financiers objectives in the rural
            sector hindered implementation, which should have been
            agreed at the early stages of the project.
